document_title: Blood in the urine (hematuria): Causes, symptoms and diagnosis
subsection_content:
Studies show that diet does not affect nor increase the risk of hematuria in humans. However, you can reduce your risk of hematuria as well as other urinary conditions. (5)
Measures to help you prevent hematuria include:
Avoid holding in urine or urinating after sex to prevent infection; Drink plenty of water and reduce salt in your diet to prevent kidney stones; Limit or do not smoke, abuse alcohol and other stimulants

Blood in the urine is a common symptom of urinary system diseases. There are two types of hematuria, macroscopic and microscopic. Gross hematuria can be clearly recognized because the patient's urine is pink or red, sometimes containing blood clots. Microscopic hematuria can only be known when the patient performs a urine test, because at this time the amount of red blood cells in the urine is abnormally high but not enough to change the color of the urine.
The disease can be cured completely by treating the cause of hematuria, mostly urinary diseases. These diseases are not too dangerous and can be treated simply with medication. However, patients need to be treated immediately upon detection to limit the risk of other complications of the disease.
